## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:


# ======================================================
# Worksheet 1 - CS101 : R Programming
# ======================================================

# -------------------------
# Part 1: Vector operations
# -------------------------

age <- c(25, 30, 18, 22, 45, 60, 32, 27, 28, 31, 29, 26, 33, 41, 22, 37, 50)

# 1. How many data points?
length(age)

# 2. Minimum and maximum value
min(age)
max(age)

# 3. Sorted values
sort(age)

# 4. Add 61 into the vector
age <- c(age, 61)
age

# 5. Add duplicate value (22)
age <- c(age, 22)
age

# 6. Smallest and largest value again
min(age)
max(age)

# -------------------------
# Part 2: Another dataset
# -------------------------

age2 <- c(24, 25, 24, 30, 28, 21, 26, 29, 25, 30, 24, 29, 25, 27)

# Minimum and maximum
min(age2)
max(age2)

# Multiply dataset by 2
age3 <- age2 * 2
age3

# -------------------------
# Part 3: Sequences
# -------------------------

# Integers from 1 to 500
seq1 <- 1:500

# Multiples of 3 between 1 and 500
seq3 <- seq(3, 500, by = 3)

# Multiples of 5 between 20 and 500
seq5 <- seq(20, 500, by = 5)

# Multiples of 4 between 120 and 320
seq4 <- seq(120, 320, by = 4)

# Sequence from 5 to 50, increment by 5
seq6 <- seq(5, 50, by = 5)

# Sequence from 1 to 1000, increment by 3
seq7 <- seq(1, 1000, by = 3)

# Numbers between 1â€“100 not divisible by 3, 5, 7
seq8 <- (1:100)[(1:100) %% 3 != 0 & (1:100) %% 5 != 0 & (1:100) %% 7 != 0]

# -------------------------
# Part 4: Random numbers
# -------------------------

set.seed(123)   # reproducibility
sample(1:500, 10)   # 10 random numbers

# -------------------------
# Part 5: Multiples of 3 or 5 below 25
# -------------------------

nums <- (1:24)[(1:24) %% 3 == 0 | (1:24) %% 5 == 0]
nums
sum(nums)

# -------------------------
# Part 6: Character vector
# -------------------------

v <- c("A", "B", "C", "D", "A", "B", "C")
v

# -------------------------
# Part 7: Handling NA values
# -------------------------

x <- c(2, 4, NA, 6, NA, 8)
x[is.na(x)] <- 0
x

# -------------------------
# Part 8: Class of objects
# -------------------------

y <- c(2.3, 4.5, 6.7)
class(y)

z <- c("a", "b", "c")
class(z)

m <- c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE)
class(m)

# -------------------------
# Part 9: Extra examples
# -------------------------

name <- "Marian Apuli"
age_num <- 20

print(paste("My name is", name, "and I am", age_num, "years old."))

print(seq(1, 10, by = 2))
print(sample(1:100, 5))

print(R.version.string)  # R version
